header.title: Sexism in Korea
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: We talk about sexism in Korea.  Well, we just talk about our experiences of sexism in Korea.  This isn't a commentary about Korea as a whole, backed up by any polls or stats or facts or anything.  We've lived here for five years: what's it been like for us?  Have we experienced sexism in any way? Let us know your thoughts on the matter as well.  It's a serious topic, one that can't be done justice with just our perspective on it, so let us know what you think in the comments.  We also write a bit more about it in our blog, so check that out, too. Subscribe for more Videos! http://www.youtube.com/subscription_c... Read more about it on our blog: http://www.eatyourkimchi.com/sexism-i... Check it out on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/EatYourKimchi... Chat with us on Twitter. http://www.twitter.com/eatyourkimchi
header.socioLingVar: Gender - General,Age - Youngsters,Physical Identity - Physical (and Mental) Impairments

I was once with a Korean girl in my dorm, having some drinks with my friends, and at one point she asked me if I knew where she'd left her glass. That's just one example, of course. But, still, Koreans have a long way to go if they wanna get to the 21st century.

I lived in Seoul, Korea for 2 years, and I've had many Korean friends before that. I went to college in Seoul. I have also worked for a big Korean company. I've seen it from the inside. I'm a Korean female myself and a professional woman in STEM. I agree that sexism is bigger in Korea, which is changing but not fast enough. Unfortunately, I can't deny it and am not even trying to do so. A lot of things still need to be changed. Men sometimes referring female employees or students as flowers nauseate me and of course no one ever dared to refer me that way. However, it's not like I don't have Korean guy friends or never dated Korean guys... In fact, I grew up in Korea and have family & friends there, thus still visit Korea often. The girl who was surprised by your simple gesture seems VERY exaggerated but maybe she's from a super oddly mysogynistic family?? Unless all of my Korean female friends and family members are way more aggressive or confident than the rest of Korean women, I seriously cannot think of any one who would be so moved by such simple gesture like she did. Same thing goes to Korean guys - at least out of people I know even including my grandfather, I can't think of that much of douche bags who wouldn't even grab a glass. Plus, being sweet, nice, and caring has been the virtue for Korean guys for a long time now. I'm not sayin g sexism doesn't exist or isn't worse but just pointing out that your experience seems quite far up in the spectrum.

@Jenn E I think I understood, and I do disagree. What I'm saying it that there is no "real" sexism vs "non-real" sexism . Sexism is sexism. To put it in another perspective, the harsh, vi olent sexism in some middle-Eastern countries does not invalida te the sexism in Korea. Whether it be hosts or brand representatives, if they are male, what you were inferring to in your video might be correct. But the main reason is not because they are looking down on you and seeing women as inferior. It is because handshakes are just not as commonplace as they are in Western countries. In US, when we first meet somebody in a semi-professional or professional setting, we'll shake their hand. In Korea, we'll bow. Thus, since the whole "shaking the hand" concept is not as common, some people are just careful to initiate a handshake. Especially because the shows that you come out on or the meetings you attend, you are accompanied by your husband. They are most likely not shaking your hand out of courtesy because in Korea, men simply do not shake somebody's wife's hand or touch them at all.

PS If you are even being held by your wrists and can't break away, you take your hand and make a fist. Whatever side the attacker's palm is on, you do a QUICK and FORCEFUL windmill motion with your arm as you also step back. This knocks them off their balance while also immediately freeing your wrist. Take whatever aggressive action might be needed if attacker is not thwarted--- heel of hand to nose, fingers to the eyes,knee to nose or groin, or stomp their foot with your heel, and haul ass outta there once you're sure they won't chase you.

replies.commentText: Maybe if they were in Canada and the Koreans were coming to them, but when you are in a foreign country you adapt to their customs. As a foreigner doing business in Korea, you are not just talking to the person or people that are in the meeting with you, you are talking to everyone they know or do business with. Getting a reputation of being confrontational over issues not directly related to business is a very bad thing. The better way of addressing a perceived slight would be to wait for a break in the meeting (or until the end) and then inform the most junior person of your discomfort with the situation (they will inform the boss at an appropriate time). Only the most egregious behavior should be directly addressed (insults about intelligence, sexual remarks, groping), and if you have to do so in a meeting, you can assume there will be no business with that person.

@George Ford  In Korea there are female business owners. They don't all just step down and let the men do it all. They have to fight harder and demand the respect their male counterparts would get automatically. It is their own country, and yet they don't say "well, that's how it's always been. I'll just deal with it".

You can demand respect without it having to come down to a confrontation. It is hard to get past someone's cultural habit, but persistence may eventually pay off.

@George Ford So subtle sexism and racism should stay if it's a cultural thing? that's a pretty horrible attitude to have; all cultures change over time to adapt with better equality and rising humane standards, especially these days. Just because it's a cultural thing to have cannibalism in some places doesn't mean it's okay or shouldn't be changed, and the same can be applied t o sexism a nd racism, when they discriminate against groups of people. You can also address these issues without becoming confrontational. I think it's horrible that Martina isn't regarded as a capable human being just because she' s a woman, don't you?

I just wanted to know how you experience   sexism in North America. I am sure sexism towards men can exist, but can you please list some examples?

Amorous Cleopatra   The "stupid man" the "all men are boys",  the "man flu" and the list goes on.  These are but a few of the male stereotypes commonly portrayed in the media allowed in the work place and generally accepted or un challenged in general by typical western Canadian or North American values.  To say similar things about women could get a man fired and yet a woman can typically safely say similarly offensive remarks without worry or retribution.  I would say that any comment you can imagine a man saying about a woman and being labeled as sexist is sexist if turned around and aimed at men.    How about the "dead beat dad" ? Now that is one I have experience with as a single father after my wife ran off on the kids and me- but we really do not have the image of the "dead beat mom".  There is more involved here than semantics.  How about the fact that if there is a domestic dispute it is the man who is always arrested?  Even if it is obvious that the female was abusing the man?  Our policies on "equal opportunity" are geared in th e woman's favor.  Many of the things we do made sense 50 or 60 years ago but now days when study after study show women to earn the same pay as men in the work place when you look at job to job comparisons there is no longer a need to offer all the incentives to women.  Or all the advantages a woman has in getting a business started, banks love to give money to young women over young men in similar circumstances because of Government policies and benefits.  There are so many ways men get a raw deal but I will leave it at that. Holy shit! I am absolutely appalled by the drag by the wrist thing. That shit is messed up!  Indian society (which is very very different in urban and rural areas. It also depends on the region of the country where you live) is not very receptive to women smoking. Outside my college in Mumbai there is a small cigarette vendor where students usually go to smoke. Since this is a post-graduate institute, all of my fellow students are legal adults in India and at least 21 years old. The women who would come out and smoke with the men would be met with disapproving glares from passers-by. Girls who smoke may also sometimes be associated with other things that are considered "immoral" like drinking (kind of a taboo, especially for women), casual pre-marita l sex (again big no-no) and drugs. These women will be considered "loose" and may fall prey to victim-blaming in cases of something li ke sexual assault.

The most logical assessment, as I see it: culture is not an acceptable excuse for limiting the rights and civil liberties of a group of people, ever. Culture is also not an acceptable excuse for ignoring a breach of civil liberties, even in societies that would consider speaking up rude or inappropriate, like some Asian societies. Last, the reception you get for speaking up will depend on how you deliver the message, not the message itself - had Simon pointed out to these companies that they were/are alienating and insulting foreign investors and consumers, Martina might have been shown a bit more respect. Money is always the bottom line.

It IS sexism, and many cultural traditions are steeped in it (especially countries with Confucian values, like Korea). But that's ok: the first step to getting rid of sexism is recognize it. Married or not, no person is more important than another based on thei r gender. If you're doing business with two people who happen to be married, you treat both of them with the same amount of respect—and you shake both their hands. That's it.
The same is with girls farting in guys. Or burping. That they can't do it on the first date. To each their own I guess.

I understand what you're saying, but that's precisely what sexism is. If I were a woman, and a woman whom my husband and I were doing business with spoke to him during the meeting and shook his hand, would that be considered disrespectful? By default, a patriarchal society considers the man more important, and that's why talking to/touching his wife is "disrespectful" because she is "hi s" woman. But that's ownership, not partnership.

The point is that if it's considered unattractive for women to be seen smoking, then the same public opinion should be held of men—but it's not. Doesn't that seem unfair?

(Btw I personally think smoking is a disgusting habit across the board. But it's the principle, you know?)
